perturbation.original_text: HOVIONE agrees to deliver the API DDP Menlo Park, CA USA (Incoterms 2010).
perturbation.changed_text: HOVIONE agrees to deliver the API Ex Works (EXW) HOVIONE's Manufacturing Facility (Incoterms 2010).
perturbation.explanation: The original contract specifies DDP (Delivered Duty Paid) Menlo Park, CA USA, meaning HOVIONE is responsible for all costs and risks associated with delivering the API to Menlo Park, CA, including import duties and taxes. By changing this to EXW (Ex Works) HOVIONE's Manufacturing Facility, the responsibility for all shipping costs, risks, and import duties/taxes is shifted to INTERSECT. This creates a legal contradiction because under California Commercial Code, the seller has a duty to properly deliver the goods as specified in the contract. Shifting the responsibility entirely to the buyer may violate these provisions, especially if INTERSECT is not properly informed or equipped to handle the import process, potentially exposing them to unforeseen liabilities and violating consumer protection laws regarding fair business practices.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Commercial Code ยง2-319, et seq. (regarding F.O.B. and F.A.S. terms); potential violation of consumer protection laws related to fair business practices

perturbation.original_text: HOVIONE shall invoice INTERSECT upon dispatch of the API. INTERSECT shall pay the price to HOVIONE for API within thirty (30) calendar days of the date of invoice of such API. Payments shall be made to HOVIONE by wire transfer.
perturbation.changed_text: HOVIONE shall invoice INTERSECT upon dispatch of the API. INTERSECT shall pay the price to HOVIONE for API within sixty (60) calendar days of the date of invoice of such API. Payments shall be made to HOVIONE by wire transfer.
perturbation.explanation: This change extends the payment terms from 30 to 60 days. Although seemingly minor, this can be problematic under California law if it is implemented without explicit agreement from HOVIONE because the default payment expectation will be breached. Adding such a large shift could be construed as an unfair business practice if it puts undue financial strain on HOVIONE without prior informed consent. This could lead to a legal dispute over breach of contract and potential violations of California's consumer protection laws regarding fair and transparent business dealings.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Commercial Code, Unfair Competition Law (California Business and Professions Code Section 17200)

perturbation.original_text: During the term of this Agreement and for a period [*] after any expiration or termination of this Agreement, each of INTERSECT and HOVIONE shall maintain in full force and effect a comprehensive general liability insurance policy, including Products Liability coverage, with minimum limits of [*] for bodily injury including death.
perturbation.changed_text: During the term of this Agreement, each of INTERSECT and HOVIONE shall maintain a general liability insurance policy. There is no requirement for Product Liability coverage, nor are there minimum limits stated for bodily injury including death.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause mandates comprehensive general liability insurance with product liability coverage and minimum limits. By removing the product liability coverage requirement and eliminating the minimum coverage limits, this modification creates significant legal risk. California law, including the California Civil Code and related case law, holds manufacturers and distributors strictly liable for defective products that cause injury. Removing product liability coverage makes it significantly more difficult for injured parties to recover damages and exposes both companies to potentially massive uninsured liabilities. This contradicts the implied duty to protect consumers from harm caused by defective products, which is a fundamental principle in California law.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Civil Code ยง1714 (regarding negligence); California product liability law (strict liability for defective products)
